At least three of the seven known attackers and the suspected ringleader, Abdelhamid Abaaoud [...] are thought to have crossed clandestinely from Syria into Europe.}}</ref> The attacks prompted European officials to re-evaluate their stance toward migrants and border controls, insisting that greater scrutiny was needed in vetting migrants.<ref name=ParisAttacksMigrants1>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/16/world/europe/paris-attacks-shift-europes-migrant-focus-to-security.html?rref=collection%2Fnewseventcollection%2Fattacks-in-paris&action=click&contentCollection=europe&region=rank&module=package&version=highlights&contentPlacement=1&pgtype=collection|title=Paris Attacks Shift Europe's Migrant Focus to Security|author1=Rick Lyman |author2=Alison Smale |lastauthoramp=yes |newspaper=The New York Times|date=15 November 2015|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=ParisAttacksMigrants2>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/11/14/world/europe/ap-eu-germany-migrants-rising-tensions.html|title=Paris Attacks Provoke Fresh Migrant Fears in Europe|author=Eldar Emric, Demetri Nellas, and the Associated Press|newspaper=The New York Times|date=14 November 2015|accessdate=16 November 2015}}</ref> *24 November: Sweden announced that it would be introducing temporary border checks to control the flow of migrants into the country, meaning that none would be allowed to cross the border without identification. It also announced that most refugees would receive only temporary residence permits from April. Prime Minister [[Stefan Löfven]] said "It pains me that Sweden is no longer capable of receiving asylum seekers at the high level we do today". Deputy Prime Minister, [[Åsa Romson]], burst into tears as she announced the measures.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/24/sweden-asylum-seekers-refugees-policy-reversal |title=Sweden slams shut its open-door policy towards refugees |date=2015-11-24 |website=The Guardian |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *28 November: Finnish authorities reported that asylum applications had reached more than 30,000 since the start of the year, and that reception centres were quickly running out of room.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/reception_centres_use_containers_to_house_new_arrivals/8486826 |title=Reception centres use containers to house new arrivals |date=2015-11-28 |website=Yle |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *28 November: Macedonia began building [[Macedonian border barrier|a barrier]] along part of its border with Greece. There were clashes between migrants and Macedonian riot police, which left up to 40 people injured.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-34954127 |title=Stranded migrants battle police on Greece-Macedonia border |date=2015-11-28 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
=== December 2015 === * 8–9 December: At least 21 migrants, including seven children, drowned when four boats sank off the Greek island of Farmakonisi.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/13-migrants-killed-as-two-boats-capsize-off-aegean-coast.aspx?PageID=238&NID=92261&NewsCatID=341 |title=13 migrants killed as two boats capsize off Aegean coast |date=2015-12-09 |website=Hurriyet Daily News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> * 16 December: [[2015 Geldermalsen riot]] – 2,000 people protested against plans to build a centre for asylum seekers in the Dutch town of [[Geldermalsen]]. There were clashes with police, during which several people were injured and officers fired warning shots.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35118496 |title=Migrant crisis: Dutch town riots over asylum centre plan |date=2015-12-17 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> * 16 December: The [[Solberg's Cabinet|Norwegian government]] created the new cabinet office of Minister of Migration amid record-high numbers of asylum seekers in Norway, having received a total of 30,000 during 2015, which eventually resulted in a broad parliamentary consensus to tighten asylum regulations. The position was filled by [[Sylvi Listhaug]], who vowed to make Norway's asylum policies "one of the strictest in Europe".<ref>{{Cite news|title=Norway: New Ministry Is Created to Address Influx of Migrants|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/17/world/europe/norway-new-ministry-is-created-to-address-influx-of-migrants.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=16 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=– Vi kommer til å få en asylpolitikk som er blant de strengeste i Europa [– We will get an asylum policy that is among the strictest in Europe]|url=http://www.nrk.no/norge/_-vi-kommer-til-a-fa-en-asylpolitikk-som-er-blant-de-strengeste-i-europa-1.12724216|publisher=NRK|date=29 December 2015|language=Norwegian}}</ref> * 30 December: The UN refugee agency reported that more than one million migrants and refugees had reached Europe by sea during 2015. More than 80% arrived in Greece from Turkey, while most of the others arrived in Italy from Libya. It recorded that 3,735 had died or were lost at sea.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35194360 |title=Migrant crisis: Over one million reach Europe by sea |date=2015-12-30 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
== 2016 == [[File:Refugees on a boat crossing the Mediterranean sea, heading from Turkish coast to the northeastern Greek island of Lesbos, 29 January 2016.jpg|thumb|Migrants crossing the Aegean Sea from Turkey to the Greek island of Lesbos, January 2016]]
=== January 2016 === *1 January: [[New Year's Eve sexual assaults in Germany]] – During the 2016 New Year's Eve celebrations, hundreds of sexual assaults, numerous thefts, and at least five rapes were reported in several German cities, mostly in [[Cologne]] city centre. The Chief Prosecutor stated that "the overwhelming majority" of suspects were asylum seekers and illegal immigrants who had recently arrived from North Africa and the Middle East.<ref>{{cite news|title=Prosecutors say most of suspects in a series of robberies and sexual assaults in Cologne during New Year's celebrations are refugees|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2016-02-15/cologne-prosecutor-majority-of-suspects-are-asylum-seekers|accessdate=28 May 2017|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Usnews.com]]|date=15 February 2016}}</ref> The attacks led to a hardening of attitudes against mass immigration, and fuelled debate about the sustainability of [[Asylum in Germany|Germany's asylum policy]] and social differences between European and Islamic countries. The German government also proposed changing the law to make it easier to deport immigrants convicted of crimes.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35261988 |title=Cologne attacks' profound impact on Europe |date=2016-01-11 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *4 January: Sweden introduced checks on its border with Denmark to stem the inflow of migrants. The changes mean that none may cross the border without identification, and transport companies will be fined if travellers do not have valid identification. Sweden's state-owned train operator [[SJ AB|SJ]] said it would stop services to and from Denmark because it could not carry out the checks needed. In response, Denmark tightened border controls with Germany.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35218921 |title=Migrant crisis: Sweden border checks come into force |date=2016-01-04 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *9 January: In Cologne, about 1,700 people joined a [[PEGIDA]] demonstration in protest at the New Year's Eve assaults and called for Chancellor Angela Merkel to resign. When police tried to disperse the rally, some protesters threw missiles and police responded by firing tear gas and water cannon. Leftists held a counter-demonstration nearby. The following day, eleven immigrants were beaten by a group of vigilantes in the area where the assaults took place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.de/20160109/violence-erupts-at-cologne-far-right-demo |title=Violence erupts at Cologne Pegida demo |date=2016-01-09 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *11 January: Swedish police launched an internal investigation after allegations arose that the police and journalists covered up [[We Are Sthlm sexual assaults|mass sexual assaults by immigrant youths at a music festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35285086 |title=Swedish police probe 'cover-up of migrant sex assaults' |date=2016-01-11 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> Shortly after, it emerged that police in Sweden would no longer be allowed to give ethnic descriptions of criminal suspects. This was to avoid pointing out immigrant groups as criminal and to avoid accusations of racism.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/swedish-police-are-not-allowed-to-give-descriptions-of-alleged-criminals-so-as-not-to-sound-racist-a6810311.html |title=Swedish police banned from describing criminals anymore in case they sound racist |date=2016-01-14 |website=The Independent |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *25 January: [[Death of Alexandra Mezher]] – A Swedish woman, Alexandra Mezher, was stabbed to death by an asylum seeker at the [[Mölndal]] refugee centre where she worked. The incident led to a marked rise in violence against immigrants and support for far-right groups.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fatal stabbing at asylum centre shocks Sweden|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-35406072|accessdate=4 June 2017|work=BBC News|date=26 January 2016}}</ref> *26 January: The Danish parliament passed a law allowing the government to seize valuables from asylum seekers to pay for their upkeep. It applies to valuables worth over 10,000 [[Danish krone|kroner]] but not those of sentimental value. The law was widely criticized by human rights groups.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35406436 |title=Denmark approves controversial migrant assets bill |date=2016-01-26 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *26 January: A gun battle broke out in the [[Grande-Synthe]] migrant camp in northern France. Police believe the fight erupted between rival gangs of people smugglers against a backdrop of tensions between Muslims and Christians in the camp. A senior [[Compagnies Républicaines de Sécurité|CRS]] officer claimed "The Muslims are trying to expel the Christians from the camp".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/12124977/Religious-tensions-spark-gunfight-in-French-migrant-camp.html |title='Religious tensions' spark gunfight in French migrant camp |date=2016-01-27 |website=The Telegraph |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *27–28 January: Twenty-six migrants, ten of them children, drowned when their boat capsized off the Greek island of [[Samos]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35430667 |title=Migrant crisis: 26 drown off Samos island near Turkey |date=2016-01-28 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *29 January: In Sweden, up to 100 black-clad masked men marched to [[Stockholm Central Station]] and attacked young immigrants. They handed out leaflets claiming the immigrants had regularly been assaulting and robbing people at the station, and called for action against immigrant crime. This led to clashes with police.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/20160130/masked-marchers-beat-migrants-in-stockholm-centre |title=Masked marchers beat immigrants in Stockholm |date=2016-01-30 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
=== February 2016 === *6 February: The [[Turkish Foreign Ministry]] announced tighter visa restrictions on [[Iraqi citizenship|Iraqi citizens]] going to [[Turkey]] as a sign of determination to combat illegal immigration to [[Europe]]. Previously, Iraqis were allowed to enter Turkey visa-free for 30 days. Now, they are required to pre-apply for either an electronic or a paper visa to enter the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Turkey tightens visa rules for Iraqi citizens 'to fight illegal immigration'|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-3434997/Turkey-tightens-visa-rules-Iraqi-citizens-fight-illegal-immigration.html|website=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Agence-France Presse]]|date=6 February 2016}}</ref> *7 February: At least 27 migrants, including 11 children, drowned when their boat capsized in the [[Gulf of Edremit]], Turkey.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/08/refugee-crisis-dead-turkey-aegean-coast-greece |title=Refugee crisis: at least 27 people die off Turkish coast |date=2016-02-08 |website=The Guardian |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *9 & 14 February: On the Greek island of [[Kos]], hundreds of locals protested against the building of a screening centre for migrants and refugees. There were clashes with police, who fired tear gas and stun grenades.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nick|first1=Squires|title=Greek riot police fire tear gas at crowds protesting against new migrant 'hotspot' on island of Kos|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/12156571/Greek-riot-police-fire-tear-gas-at-crowds-protesting-against-new-migrant-hotspot-on-island-of-Kos.html|accessdate=2016-05-01|date=14 Feb 2016|language=en}}</ref> Petrol bombs were also thrown at officers, and a homemade bomb exploded outside the police station.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kos island to hold referendum on disputed refugee hot spot {{!}} Kathimerini|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/205796/article/ekathimerini/news/kos-island-to-hold-referendum-on-disputed-refugee-hot-spot|accessdate=2016-05-01|date=2016-02-09|language=en}}</ref> *11 February: Turkish President, [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]], threatened to send millions of refugees from Turkey into the EU unless Turkey is given more funds to host the refugees. Meanwhile, NATO agreed to send a patrol of three ships to the [[Aegean Sea|Aegean]] to intercept migrants trying to reach Greece and to send them back to Turkey.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/12/turkish-president-threatens-to-send-millions-of-syrian-refugees-to-eu |title=Turkish president threatens to send millions of Syrian refugees to EU |date=2016-02-12 |website=The Guardian |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *15 February: Leaders of [[Visegrad Group]] met with their counterparts from Bulgaria and Macedonia in Prague and announced that [[Balkan route]] should be closed on Greek-Macedonian border by mid March, if Greece fails to protect its southern border. Visegrad countries will help Macedonia and other balkan countries with protection of their borders.<ref>{{cite web|title=Visegrad countries call for 'alternative plan' to counter migration crisis|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/central-europe/news/visegrad-countries-call-for-alternative-plan-to-counter-migration-crisis/|website=EURACTIV.com}}</ref> *15 February: Bulgaria announced that it will close all its external EU borders and deport anyone who does not meet the criteria for asylum.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2016-02-15/bulgaria-to-close-all-external-eu-borders-pm-announces/ |title=Bulgaria to close all external EU borders, PM announces |date=2016-02-15 |website=ITV News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *17 February: Austria announced that it will introduce checks on its border with Hungary, Slovenia and Italy to stem the inflow of migrants. It also announced it will set a daily cap on the number of asylum seekers allowed to enter the country and limit daily asylum claims. The EU's Migration Commissioner said the cap on asylum claims would break EU and international law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dw.com/en/austria-sets-migrant-cap-throws-up-border-controls/a-19054329 |title=Austria sets migrant cap, throws up border controls |date=2016-02-17 |website=Deutsche Welle |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *23 February: Belgium introduced temporary controls on its border with France to prevent a potential inflow of UK-bound migrants from the [[Migrants around Calais|Calais migrant camps]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/belgium/12170920/Belgium-reintroduces-border-controls-with-France-to-prevent-influx-of-Calais-migrants.html |title=Belgium reintroduces border controls with France to prevent influx of Calais migrants |date=2016-02-23 |website=The Telegraph |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *23 February: Norwegian Prime Minister [[Erna Solberg]] proposed ''force majeure'' emergency legislation that would allow rejecting all asylum seekers coming to Norway. The measures, which would break international law, would be implemented in the case of a "complete breakdown" of neighbouring Sweden's asylum system.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Norway wants to deny all refugees if 'it all breaks down'|url=http://www.thelocal.no/20160223/norwegian-pm-proposes-stricter-refugee-laws|work=The Local|date=23 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Norge vil bryde folkeretten og afvise flygtninge i krisetilfælde [Norway wants to break international law and reject refugees in an emergency situation]|url=http://www.b.dk/nationalt/norge-vil-bryde-folkeretten-og-afvise-flygtninge-i-krisetilfaelde|work=Berlingske|date=20 February 2016|language=Danish}}</ref> *24 February: The Hungarian government announced that it will hold a [[Hungarian migrant quota referendum, 2016|referendum on the EU's mandatory migrant quotas]]. The European Commission criticized the decision, while European Parliament president [[Martin Schulz]] condemned it as a "populist and nationalist response to a global challenge".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euronews.com/2016/02/25/eu-s-schulz-slams-hungary-s-populist-migrant-referendum/ |title=EU's Schulz slams Hungary's 'populist' migrant referendum |date=2016-02-25 |website=Euronews |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *25 February: Greece recalled its ambassador to Austria amid sharp divisions over the migrant crisis. Meanwhile, the EU's Migration Commissioner warned that the EU's migration system could "completely break down" within weeks.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35658776 |title=Migrant crisis: Greece recalls |date=2016-02-25 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *26 February: Two Pakistani migrants tried to publicly hang themselves in front of onlookers in the centre of [[Athens]], in protest at being stranded in Greece.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/12174453/Migrants-attempt-to-hang-themselves-in-the-centre-of-Athens.html |title=Migrants attempt to hang themselves in the centre of Athens |date=2016-02-26 |website=The Telegraph |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *29 February: There were clashes as French authorities began demolishing part of the '[[Calais Jungle]]' migrant camp. Migrants and [[No Border network|'No Borders' activists]] threw stones and set shacks ablaze while about 150 migrants, some wielding iron bars, ran onto the road to block vehicles. Riot police responded with tear gas. The government wanted to move migrants to official accommodation made from converted shipping containers, but most refused, fearing they would be forced to claim asylum in France rather than Britain.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35686209 |title=EU migrant crisis: Clashes as France clears Calais 'Jungle' |date=2016-02-28 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
=== March 2016 === *2 March: NATO's [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe|Supreme Commander in Europe]] claimed that Russia and the Assad regime in Syria were using mass migration as an "aggressive strategy against Europe".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35706238 |title=Migrant crisis: Russia and Syria 'weaponising' migration |date=2016-03-02 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *5 March: Twenty-five migrants drowned when their boat sank off the coast of [[Didim]], Turkey.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35739555 |title=Migrant crisis: Boat sinking off Didim, Turkey claims 25 lives |date=2016-03-06 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *7 March: Several hundred residents of Calais held a protest in Paris against the "economic catastrophe" in their town, which they say has been caused by the [[Calais migrant crisis|migrant crisis there]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/calais-residents-protest-over-economic-catastrophe-of-camp-1.2563492 |title=Calais residents protest over 'economic catastrophe' of camp |date=2016-03-08 |website=The Irish Times |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *7 March: Police in [[Östersund]], Sweden, warned women not to go out alone at night, after a spate of sexual assaults against women and girls by immigrant men. The warning was criticized by the city's [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democrat]] mayor and others.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.se/20160308/backlash-begins-after-swedish-women-told-not-to-go-out-alone |title=Police defend warning for solo women in northern Sweden |date=2016-03-08 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/650919/Sweden-migrant-sex-attacks-Ostersund-women-go-out-night-refugee-centre |title=Women warned 'don't go out at night' after migrant sex attackers target 10-year-old girls |date=2016-03-10 |website=The Express |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *9 March: [[Balkans|Balkan]] countries announced tighter restrictions on migrant entry, in a bid to close the 'Balkan route'. Slovenia, Croatia, Serbia and Macedonia announced that only migrants who plan to seek asylum in the country, or those with clear humanitarian needs will be allowed entry and that those without valid documents will be turned back.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35760534 |title=Migrant crisis: Slovenia moves to 'shut down' Balkans route |date=2016-03-09 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> Hungary declared a state of emergency due to the migrant crisis, and deployed additional police and military at the borders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hungarytoday.hu/news/breaking-news-hungary-declares-state-emergency-migrant-crisis-turns-unpredictable-96001 |title=Breaking News: Hungary Declares State Of Emergency As Migrant Crisis Turns Unpredictable |date=2016-03-09 |website=Hungary Today |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> German Chancellor Angela Merkel condemned the "unilateral" closure of the Balkan route.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35772206 |title=Migrant crisis: Angela Merkel condemns closure of Balkan route|date=2016-03-10 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *12 March: In Berlin, about 3,000 people took part in a protest march against the German government's 'open door' asylum policy. It drew ten times more protesters than police had expected. The march was met by a 1,000-strong counter-demonstration.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dw.com/en/anti-foreigner-rally-in-berlin-draws-ten-times-more-protesters-than-expected/a-19113388 |title=Anti-foreigner rally in Berlin draws ten times more protesters than expected |date=2016-03-12 |website=Deutsche Welle |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *12 March: In Calais, more than 130 activists from the [[Identitarian movement]] blocked roads leading from migrant camps to the town centre. The activists set up barricades, burnt tyres and carried banners with slogans such as 'Defend Calais'. There were clashes as riot police forcibly dispersed the activists and 14 arrests were made.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/police-arrest-far-right-activists-as-protesters-block-bridges-with-burning-tyres-to-stop-refugees-a6927351.html |title=Police arrest far-right activists as protesters block bridges with burning tyres to stop refugees entering Calais |date=2016-03-12 |website=The Independent |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *13 March: The right-wing nationalist party [[Alternative for Germany]] (AFD) made strong gains in German state elections. The party campaigned against mass immigration and the German government's 'open door' asylum policy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/30d1c56100004c579237fc1193df3b63/3-german-states-vote-elections-marked-migrant-crisis |title=Nationalists strong, setback for Merkel party in German vote |date=2016-03-13 |website= |agency=Associated Press |access-date=2016-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428232449/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/30d1c56100004c579237fc1193df3b63/3-german-states-vote-elections-marked-migrant-crisis |archivedate=2016-04-28 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-germany-election-idUSKCN0WE0ZQ |title=German voters batter Merkel over migrant policy |date=2016-03-13 |website= |agency=Reuters |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *18 March: The EU and Turkey agreed a deal to tackle illegal (or 'irregular') migration. From 20 March, irregular migrants arriving in Greece will be sent back to Turkey if they do not apply for asylum or their claim is rejected. Each Syrian sent back will be replaced with a Syrian refugee who will be resettled in the EU. Turkey will take tougher action to prevent illegal migration. In return, the EU will send Turkey €3 billion to help it host refugees and will allow Turkish citizens to travel freely into the [[Schengen zone]] by June.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-35854413 |title=Migrant crisis: EU-Turkey deal comes into effect |date=2016-03-20 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
=== April 2016 === [[File:Brennerpass from north.JPG|thumb|The Brenner Pass, on the Italy-Austria border]] *3 April: Hundreds of 'No Borders' activists protested at the [[Brenner Pass]], on the Italy-Austria border, against Austria's plans for stricter border controls. Clashes broke out when activists tried to march into Austria. Some threw stones at Austrian police and tried to break through police lines. Austrian police forced them back with batons, shields and pepper spray. Ten protesters and five police were injured.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.it/20160404/pro-refugee-protesters-clash-with-police-at-austria-italy-border |title=Clashes as Austria pledges to deploy soldiers to Italy border |date=2016-04-04 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *6 April: Migrants protested at the [[Port of Piraeus]] in Greece when authorities tried to move them from a makeshift camp to official migrant shelters. One migrant threatened to throw a baby at police after they tried to stop him from smashing a car.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/207687/article/ekathimerini/news/tensions-flare-at-piraeus-port-as-migrants-refuse-to-evacuate-makeshift-camp |title=Tensions flare at Piraeus Port as migrants refuse to evacuate makeshift camp |date=2016-04-06 |website=Ekathimerini |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *10 April: Clashes erupted at the [[Idomeni]] migrant camp on the Greece-Macedonia border. Hundreds of migrants attempted to break through the border barrier and threw stones at Macedonian police. Police responded by firing tear gas, [[stun grenade]]s and [[plastic bullet]]s. More than 200 migrants and at least 15 police officers were injured. A Greek government spokesman called the Macedonian police actions "dangerous and deplorable".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/10/clashes-between-migrants-and-police-at-border-between-greece-and-macedonia |title=Hundreds hurt in police clashes at Greece-Macedonia border |date=2016-04-10 |website=The Guardian |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> Later, migrants hijacked a train carriage and attempted to use it to break through the barrier. A passenger train in which refugees were squatting was also set alight during a clash between Kurds and Afghans.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.rt.com/news/339233-idomeni-greece-police-train-migrants/ |title=Refugees use train carriage to smash police barricade on Greece-Macedonia border |date=2016-04-11 |website=RT |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *12 April: Austria began building a fence and registration center at the Brenner Pass on the Italian border. Austria's Defense Minister threatened to shut the Brenner Pass unless Italy stemmed the northward flow of migrants. The EU and refugee agencies criticized the measures.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.at/20160414/italy-must-stop-refugee-flow-or-well-shut-brenner-pass-austria |title='Italy must stop refugee flow or we'll shut Brenner pass' |date=2016-04-14 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *15 April: There were clashes between a vigilante group and hundreds of migrants at a makeshift migrant camp outside [[Stalingrad (Paris Métro)|Stalingrad metro station]], Paris. Police used tear gas to disperse the crowds, and four people were taken to hospital.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.fr/20160418/video-massive-brawl-erupts-at-paris-migrant-camp |title=Mass street brawl erupts at Paris migrant camp |date=2016-04-18 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *16 April: [[Pope Francis]] took 12 Syrian refugees back with him to [[Vatican City]] after visiting a camp on the Greek island of Lesbos. The three families, including six children, are all Muslim and had their homes bombed during the Syrian civil war. The Vatican stated that Pope Francis wanted to "make a gesture of welcome" to refugees.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36063300 |title=Migrant crisis: Pope returns from Greece with 12 migrants |date=2016-04-16 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *18 April: The Turkish government threatened to withdraw from its agreement with the EU unless the EU grants visa-free travel for Turkish citizens by June. Withdrawing from the agreement would mean that Turkey would no longer take back migrants from the EU.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20160419-turkey-migrant-deal-eu-visa-free-travel |title=Turkey threatens to back out of EU migrant deal over visas |date=2016-04-19 |website=France 24 |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *18 April: Migrants pelted Greek police with stones at Idomeni migrant camp after a migrant was hit by a police van. Police fired tear gas to break up the crowds.<ref>{{cite news|title=Migrants hurl stones at police on Greek border after man injured by van|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-greece/migrants-hurl-stones-at-police-on-greek-border-after-man-injured-by-van-idUSKCN0XF26H|accessdate=2016-05-01|work=Reuters|date=2016-04-18}}</ref> *19 April: Adverts by the organization 'Refugees Welcome' began being shown to German [[YouTube]] users when they search for anti-mass immigration videos. The adverts cannot be skipped and use YouTube's advertising system to target certain search terms.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36095659 |title=German refugees use advertising to target anti-immigration YouTube videos |date=2016-04-20 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *20 April: The Swiss government said it had drawn up plans to deploy 2,000 soldiers at border crossings should there be a major inflow of migrants to the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.ch/20160421/swiss-army-ready-to-act-in-worst-case-migrant-scenario |title=Swiss army ready to act in worst case migrant scenario |date=2016-04-21 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *24 April: [[Freedom Party of Austria|Austrian Freedom Party]] candidate [[Norbert Hofer]], campaigning against mass immigration, won the first round of voting in the [[Austrian presidential election, 2016|Austrian presidential election]]. Following the result, pressure mounted on Austrian Chancellor [[Werner Faymann]], of the [[Social Democratic Party of Austria|Social Democratic Party]], and he resigned on 9 May.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36245316 |title=Shock as Austrian Chancellor Faymann quits |date=2016-05-09 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> Hofer narrowly lost the final round in December with a record nearly 50% of the vote. Meanwhile, there were further clashes at the Brenner Pass on the Italy-Austria border between 'No Borders' protesters and Austrian police.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-brenner-protests-idUSKCN0XL0P9 |title=Austrian police clash with Italians protesting Brenner border checks |date=2016-04-24 |website= |agency=Reuters |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *25 April: Norwegian authorities began offering a 'bonus' 10,000 [[Norwegian krone|kroner]] to 500 asylum seekers willing to leave the country voluntarily. The Norwegian Directorate of Immigration (UDI) said the scheme is less costly than keeping them in asylum centres.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/26/norway-to-pay-asylum-seekers-extra-money-to-leave/ |title=Norway offers to pay asylum seekers £1000 bonus to leave the country |date=2016-04-26 |website=The Telegraph |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *26 April: There was rioting at the Moria detention center on the Greek island of Lesbos, shortly after the Greek and Dutch migration ministers toured the center. The migrants set bins on fire and threw stones at police.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-greece-clashes-idUSKCN0XN271 |title=Clashes break out at migrants camp on Greek island: police |date=2016-04-26 |website= |agency=Reuters |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref> *27 April: The Austrian parliament passed a law allowing the government to declare a state of emergency should there be another surge in immigrant numbers. The authorities would then only let in refugees under threat in a neighboring country or whose relatives are already in Austria. The "special measures" will also require migrants to request asylum at the border in registration centers, where they may be held for up to 120 hours while their application is being checked. Parliament also voted to limit the length of asylum and to make it harder for families to join them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelocal.at/20160427/austria-considers-rejecting-most-migrants-amid-far-right-surge |title=Austria votes to reject most migrants and refugees |date=2016-04-27 |website=The Local |agency= |access-date=2016-05-01}}</ref>
=== May 2016 === *4 May: The European Commission proposed fining EU member states if they do not take their quota of asylum seekers. Member states would be fined €250,000 for each asylum seeker they do not take in, with the money going to 'frontline' states such as Italy and Greece that have carried the burden.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36202490 |title=Migrant crisis: EU plans penalties for refusing asylum seekers |date=2016-05-04 |website=BBC News |agency= |access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> *5 May: When Belgian police found dozens of migrants in a lorry at [[Nieuwpoort, Belgium|Nieuwpoort]], four Iraqi people-smugglers fled in a car, sparking a [[Car chase|high-speed chase]] into France. Police shot at the car, which later crashed near [[Dunkirk]]. The chase caused several accidents and a motorcyclist was killed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36212709 |title='People smugglers in British car' shot in chase in France |date=2016-05-05 |website= |agency= |access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> *7 May: There were clashes at the Brenner Pass, on the Italy-Austria border, for the third time in a month. Hundreds of anarchists, protesting against stricter border controls, threw stones and firecrackers at Italian police, who responded with tear gas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-europe-migrants-border-brenner-idUSKCN0XY07Y |title=Italian police, demonstrators clash in protest against Austrian fence |date=2016-05-07 |website= |agency=Reuters |access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> *9 May: A Syrian migrant was shot and badly wounded by Slovak border guards on the Slovakia-Hungary border. The guards had tried to shoot out the tires of four cars, which tried to illegally cross the border at speed. Six alleged smugglers and 11 migrants were arrested.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/05/09/syrian-refugee-shot-by-slovakian-border-guards/ |title=Syrian refugee shot by Slovakian border guards |date=2016-05-09 |website=The Telegraph |agency= |access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref>
=== September 2016 === *14 September: The [[Egyptian Navy]] announced they have stopped two fishing boats bound for [[Europe]] carrying a total of 440 migrants during the [[Eid al-Adha]] holiday in the [[Kafr El Sheikh Governorate]]. The boats were later diverted back to [[Alexandria, Egypt|Alexandria]], were the migrants received medical care by the authorities. The seized fishing boats were later refereed for prosecution.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt's navy foils irregular immigration attempt of 440 people|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/243951/Egypt/Politics-/Egypt%E2%80%99s-navy-foils-irregular-immigration-attempt-o.aspx|publisher=Ahram Online|date=14 September 2016}}</ref> *21 September: In the [[2016 Egypt migrant shipwreck]] a boat capsized off the Egyptian coast with around 600 refugees on board in the Mediterranean Sea headed towards Europe. 204 bodies were recovered after the tragedy.
=== November 2016 === *3 November: In the [[November 2016 Libya migrant shipwrecks]] around 240 migrants were killed in two capsized boats off the coast of Libya.
== 2017 == === March 2017 === *17 March: In the wake of tensions between [[2017 Dutch–Turkish diplomatic incident|Turkey and several European nations]] over the [[Turkish constitutional referendum, 2017]], Turkish [[Ministry of the Interior (Turkey)|interior minister]] [[Süleyman Soylu]] threatened to [[European migrant crisis|send 15,000 refugees]] to the [[European Union]] every month while foreign minister [[Mevlut Cavusoglu]] has also threatened to [[EU-Turkey deal|cancel the March 2016 EU-Turkey migrant deal]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nu.nl/buitenland/4549128/turkije-dreigt-met-sturen-migranten-europese-unie.html |title= Turkije dreigt met sturen migranten naar Europese Unie |language= nl |work= [[NU.nl]] |year= 2017 |access-date= 17 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/turkey-threatens-to-send-europe-15000-refugees-a-month/28375772.html|title=Turkey Threatens To Send Europe 15,000 Refugees A Month|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|accessdate=28 June 2018}}</ref> *24 March : At least 240 refugees and migrants are feared to have died after two boats capsized in the Mediterranean Sea, according to a Spanish aid organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/refugees-240-migrants-drown-mediterranean-sea-boats-capsize-north-africa-europe-crisis-a7647201.html|title=More than 240 refugees feared drowned in the Mediterranean after rubber boats capsize|publisher=The Independent|date=24 March 2017}}</ref>
=== May 2017 === *8 May : Approximately 80 migrants from Libya died in the Mediterranean Sea trying to reach Italy, the [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA News Agency]] said. Another 40 survivors were rescued by a coast guard ship and taken to the [[port of Pozzallo]], Italy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/europe/80-migrants-dead-in-mediterranean-trying-to-reach-italy/813470|title=80 migrants dead in Mediterranean trying to reach Italy|publisher=Anadolu Agency|date=8 May 2017}}</ref> *24 May : At least 34 migrants, many of them young children, drowned in the Mediterranean Sea off Libya's coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/world/europe/at-least-34-migrants-drown-in-the-mediterranean/news-story/7e0eac8060ae479f68dcc535dcff5da8|title=At least 34 migrants drown in the Mediterranean|publisher=News.com Australia|date=25 May 2017}}</ref>
=== June 2017 === *16 June : 906 refugees, including 92 women and 25 children were picked up by the Libyan coast guard seven kilometers from [[Sabratha]], Libya on the Mediterranean Sea, according to a Libyan official.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/africa/more-than-900-refugees-caught-by-libyan-coast-guard/843297|title=More than 900 refugees caught by Libyan coast guard|publisher=Anadolu Agency|date=2017-06-17}}</ref>
=== September 2017 === *24 September: The anti-immigration [[Alternative for Germany]] (AfD) became the first nationalist party to enter the German [[Bundestag]] since [[World War II]], becoming [[German federal election, 2017|the third largest party overall]] and single largest opposition party. The rise of the party was directly linked to Angela Merkel's handling of the refugee crisis.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Coming from the right, Germany's AfD drawing much support from left|url=http://www.dpa-international.com/topic/coming-right-germany-afd-drawing-much-support-left-170923-99-169056|agency=DPA International|date=23 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=AfD, CDU, SPD: Where do German parties stand on refugees, asylum and immigration?|url=http://www.dw.com/en/afd-cdu-spd-where-do-german-parties-stand-on-refugees-asylum-and-immigration/a-40610988|work=Deutsche Welle|date=24 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='I am afraid': First far-right party set to enter German parliament in over half a century|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/22/first-far-right-party-to-enter-germanys-parliament-in-over-half-a-century.html|work=CNBC|date=22 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=First day on the job: Meet Germany's new far-right politicians|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/24/europe/afd-germany-parliament-first-day/index.html|work=CNBC|date=24 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Germany's far-right AfD targets refugees in first bill before parliament|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germanys-far-right-afd-targets-refugees-in-first-bill-before-parliament/a-42206338|work=Deutsche Welle|date=18 January 2018}}</ref>
=== December 2017 === *18 December: Formation of the [[Kurz government]] with the anti-immigration [[Freedom Party of Austria]] (FPÖ) following the [[Austrian legislative election, 2017|Austrian legislative election in October]]. The FPÖ as well as [[Sebastian Kurz]] campaigned against immigration in an election marked by the migrant crisis.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Austria holds watershed election marked by migrant crisis|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41625544|work=BBC News|date=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title= Austria turns sharply to the right in an election shaped by immigration|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/austrian-election-yields-a-hard-right-turn-as-conservative-and-nationalist-parties-gain/2017/10/15/d1dce850-ad22-11e7-9b93-b97043e57a22_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=16 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Austria's far-right to enter government after coalition deal|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/12/16/austrias-sebastian-kurz-strikes-deal-bring-far-right-government/|work=The Telegraph|date=16 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Austria's leader Sebastian Kurz angers Angela Merkel by refusing to shelter refugees|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/austria-s-leader-kurz-angers-merkel-by-refusing-to-shelter-refugees-qvkvms3gf|work=The Times|date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=EU to step up fight against migrants when Austria's far-right–conservative coalition chairs European Council later this year|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/eu-immigration-sebastian-kurz-illegal-migration-donald-tusk-european-council-chair-right-right-fpo-a8208561.html|work=The Independent|date=13 February 2018}}</ref>
== 2018 == === January 2018 === *9 January:[[2018 Libya migrant shipwrecks]] up to 100 migrants went missing when a rubberboat was punctured and sank off the Libyan coast. *27 January: Czech President [[Miloš Zeman]] was [[Czech presidential election, 2018|re-elected]] after a campaign against immigration, Muslim migrants and EU refugee quotas. The run-off challenger [[Jiří Drahoš]] had stated his more moderate opposition to immigration and refugee quotas.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Refugee Crisis Takes Center Stage in Czech Presidential Election|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-18/refugee-crisis-takes-center-stage-in-czech-presidential-election|work=Bloomberg|date=18 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Czech Republic Re-elects Milos Zeman, Populist Leader and Foe of Migrants|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/27/world/europe/czech-election-milos-zeman.html|work=The New York Times|date=27 January 2018}}</ref>
=== April 2018 === *8 April: The right-wing populist [[Fidesz]] party led by Hungarian Prime Minister [[Viktor Orbán]] won [[Hungarian parliamentary election, 2018|a two-thirds supermajority in parliament]], in a victory due almost entirely to a campaign against immigration and EU refugee quotas.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Hungary's Far Right Leader Is Going Nowhere—and Europe Should Be Worried|url=http://time.com/5236089/hungary-viktor-orban-clash-eu/|work=Time|date=11 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Hungary's Viktor Orban wins 'supermajority' for third consecutive term in office|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/04/09/hungary-viktor-orban-wins-supermajority-for-third-consecutive-term-in-office.html|work=CNBC|date=9 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Hungarian nationalist PM Orban on track for third straight term in power|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hungary-election-preview/hungary-pm-orban-on-track-for-third-straight-term-in-power-idUSKCN1HD160|agency=Reuters|date=6 April 2018}}</ref>
=== June 2018 === *1 June: The populist [[Government of Change]], a coalition between the [[Five Star Movement]] and [[Lega Nord]], was formed following the [[Italian general election, 2018|Italian general election in March]]. Lega leader and Interior Minister [[Matteo Salvini]] pledged to stop illegal immigration, deport 600,000 migrants and put an end to Italy and Sicily being "Europe's refugee camp".<ref>{{Cite news|title=Italy migrants: Matteo Salvini calls for end to Sicily 'refugee camp'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44346084|work=BBC News|date=3 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Italian Interior Minister Matteo Salvini: Italy not 'Europe's refugee camp'|url=http://www.dw.com/en/italian-interior-minister-matteo-salvini-italy-not-europes-refugee-camp/a-44062004|work=Deutsche Welle|date=3 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title= A political deal in Italy could lead to Western Europe's first fully populist government |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/a-political-deal-in-italy-could-lead-to-western-europes-first-fully-populist-government/2018/05/10/b9917d60-5452-11e8-a6d4-ca1d035642ce_story.html|work=The Washington Post|date=10 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=EU warns against euroscepticism as populists prepare to govern Italy|url=https://www.thelocal.it/20180511/eu-italy-populists-league-five-star-movement|website=thelocal.it|agency=AFP|date=11 May 2018}}</ref> *10 June: Italy and Malta denied entry to the NGO ship [[Aquarius (NGO ship)|Aquarius]] with 629 people on board (among them seven pregnant women, eleven small children and 123 unaccompanied minors). The migrants had embarked from Libya on inflatable boats, and were picked up off the Libyan coast.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Spain to accept disputed migrant ship Aquarius|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-44441386|work=BBC News|date=12 June 2018}}</ref> Salvini stated he wanted an end to illegal immigration and [[human trafficking]].<ref>{{Cite news|title=Five things to know about the Aquarius refugee ship|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/aquarius-refugee-ship-180613132710742.html|work=Al Jazeera|date=13 June 2018}}</ref>
=== July 2018 === *8 July: Italy's Interior Minister [[Matteo Salvini]] declared that his country would also reject foreign navy as well as [[Frontex]] ships that have boarded refugees at sea. He urged Europe's rescue missions to take refugees away from Italy's ports.<ref>[https://sputniknews.com/europe/201807081066169469-italy-block-navy-ships-migrant-rescue/ Italy Vows to Block Foreign Navy Ships on Migrant Rescue Missions From Ports]. ''Sputnik News Europe''. Retrieved 8 July 2018.</ref>

{{refimprove|date=June 2015}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox film festival | name = Tropfest | logo = TropFest Logo.jpg | founded = 1993 | location = [[Tropfest#Locations|Australia]] | language = English | website = {{URL|tropfest.com}} }} [[File:Tropfest 2011.jpg|thumb|Tropfest in Sydney, February 2011]] '''Tropfest''' is the world's largest [[short film]] [[film festival|festival]]. It has also become known as the world's first global film festival.
Founded by actor/director [[John Polson]], Tropfest began in 1993 as a screening for 200 people at the 'Tropicana Caffe' in [[Darlinghurst, Sydney]], Australia, but has since become the largest platform for short films in the world. Tropfest Australia usually takes place in December each year in Sydney and is broadcast live to various cities around Australia to an audience of approximately 150,000. Sydney Tropfest 2015 was cancelled less than a month before it was scheduled to run. After much support on social media, Tropfest founder Polson announced in early December 2015 that extra funding had been sourced, and the festival took place in [[Centennial Park, Sydney|Centennial Park]] on Sunday, 14 February 2016. In August 2016 it was announced that from February 2017 Sydney's Tropfest would be held in [[Parramatta]] in western Sydney.
==Entry requirements== Tropfest differs from other cinema events by being a "content generation" platform, rather than an exhibition platform. Filmmakers are required to create new works for the festival which must include an item, known as the "[[Tropfest#Signature item|Tropfest Signature Item]]" (TSI) and which changes each year. The films must be less than 7 minutes (including titles and credits) and be world premieres at the Tropfest event.
==History== The festival's name is derived from the first year's location—the Tropicana Caffe in [[Darlinghurst, New South Wales|Darlinghurst]], an inner-eastern suburb of Sydney.<ref name=tropcaf-hist>{{cite web|title=Tropicana Cafe - History|url=http://www.tropicanacaffe.com/index.php/history|publisher=Tropicana Cafe|accessdate=6 December 2015|date=2013}}</ref> Created by Australian-born filmmaker John Polson, the first festival was held in 1993 and was originally called the '''Tropicana Short Film Festival'''.
The support and involvement of film personalities from around the world has become one of the trademarks of the festival. Selection of the winning Tropfest film takes place live on the night of the festival by a panel of high-profile industry and celebrity judges, in addition to the previous year's winner. Past judges have included [[Nicole Kidman]], [[Cate Blanchett]], [[Naomi Watts]], [[Toni Collette]], [[Rose Byrne]], [[Geoffrey Rush]], [[Russell Crowe]], [[John Woo]], [[Samuel L. Jackson]], [[Baz Luhrmann]], [[Keanu Reeves]], [[Sam Neill]], [[Ewan McGregor]], [[Jane Campion]], [[Salma Hayek]], [[George Miller (filmmaker)|George Miller]] [[Susan Sarandon]] and [[Gabriel Byrne]]. Corporate supporters have included [[Intel]], [[Sony]], [[Qantas]], [[Cointreau]] and [[Howard Park Wines|MadFish Wines]]. [[Movie Network|Movie Extra]] used to be the primary sponsor of Tropfest Australia, which is now supported by [[CGU plc|CGU]], [[Holden]], [[Parramatta City Council]], [[Screen Australia]], [[Western Sydney University|WSU]], [[Parramatta Park, New South Wales|Parramatta Park]] and [[Melrose Park, New South Wales|Melrose Park]].
The festival attracts a wide degree of media coverage but it is the casual, [[grassroots]] nature of the event, rather than its high profile, which ensures the continued support of its patrons and guests. Notable alumni include filmmakers such as [[Alister Grierson]], [[Rowan Woods]], [[Clayton Jacobson (director)|Clayton Jacobson]], [[Joel Edgerton]], [[Nash Edgerton]], Peter Carstairs, [[Rob Carlton]], [[Sam Worthington]], [[Robert Connolly]], [[Leon Ford]], Justin Drape, Tim Bullock and [[Elissa Down]].
Tropfest now includes the popular [[Trop Jr]], a short filmmaking competition and festival for youngsters under 16.
Other Tropfest programs include:
* APRA TROPSCORE, a film scoring and synching competition, and * Nikon DSLR Film Category, a category in the competition awarding short films created using DSLR technology
==Locations== The main event from 1993 to 2016 took place in [[Sydney]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sydney.com/events|title=Sydney Events|publisher=Sydney.com|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref> but live satellite events are also staged in [[Melbourne]], [[Canberra]], [[Brisbane]], [[Adelaide]], [[Hobart]], [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] and other cities. The event is broadcast live on television by [[ABC Comedy]] and webcast to viewers around Australia and the world. In August 2016 it was announced that, beginning in February 2017, the venue would be moved to [[Parramatta]] in western Sydney.<ref name="Abc-mve-parra">{{cite news |title=Parramatta to host Tropfest |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-08-15/tropfest-short-film-festival-moves-to-parramatta/7736308 |accessdate=17 August 2016 |work=ABC News u|publisher=ABC Australia |date=15 August 2016}}</ref>
Tropfest has expanded to locations around the world including Japan, [[Turkey]], [[Africa]], [[Abu Dhabi]], [[London]], [[Berlin]], [[Toronto]], [[Bangkok]], and [[New York City]]. The inaugural [[Tropfest Arabia]], encompassing approximately 33 countries throughout the [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]], took place in Abu Dhabi in November 2011. Tropfest launched into the United States in June 2012, with a weekend-long event in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and a fully-fledged Tropfest New York competition in New York on 23 June 2012 at Manhattan's [[Bryant Park]]. Tropfest New Zealand launched in 2013 and Tropfest South East Asia at [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]] in 2014.
==Festival== [[File:Madfish tropfest 2009.jpg|thumb|right|200px| Tropfest 2009 at [[Howard Park Wines|MadFish Winery]] Margaret River, Western Australia]] In 2006 there were over 700 entrants and every year 16 finalists are screened in public parks and cafes around Australia. Sydney's annual audience of around 100,000 people attended [[The Domain, Sydney|The Domain]] to watch the finalists on three large video screens. Over 150,000 people attend Australia-wide.
The Sydney screening of Tropfest 2006 was abandoned after 13 films due to severe electrical storms. Screenings in other cities were not affected. With the judges located in Sydney it was necessary to announce the winners two days later at a press conference.
Each film must be no longer than seven minutes, have never been shown publicly before and contain the "Tropfest Signature Item", which changes each year, to show that the film was made specifically for the festival.
In April 2007, Tropfest formed a partnership with [[PBL Media]] which would see festival content archived and screened across various PBL properties and brands.<ref>{{cite news | first=Michael | last=Bodey | coauthors= | title=PBL's long-term plan for Tropfest shorts | date=19 April 2007 | publisher= | url =http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21580275-7582,00.html | work =The Australian | pages = | accessdate = 2007-04-19 | language = }}</ref>
For Tropfest 2009, pay television channel [[Movie Network|Movie Extra]] replaced Sony as the naming rights sponsor for the next seven years. A new feature in 2009 was the live national broadcast of Tropfest and screening of the finalist films on the Movie Extra channel.<ref>[http://www.bandt.com.au/dirplus/images/bttoday/newsletter/07_08_2008.pdf Tropfest loses Sony and gains Movie Extra] - B&T Today, 7 Aug 2008 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320172511/http://www.bandt.com.au/dirplus/images/bttoday/newsletter/07_08_2008.pdf |date=20 March 2009 }}</ref>
Tropfest Australia 2011 was the largest Tropfest ever staged, and reached a national audience of approximately 1,000,000 people (not including the internet).
Prior to the first full Tropfest New York competition in June 2012, Tropfest held annual New York screenings between 2006 and 2008. Signature items were a manhole cover, a slice, and a sunflower respectively. In November 2011, ahead of the 2012 competition, filmmakers were invited to "grab a camera, start shooting and tell their story through film", using the Tropfest NY 2012 Signature Item of "Bagel".
Over a weekend in June 2012, [[Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas|The Cosmopolitan]] in Las Vegas celebrated Tropfest's 20th anniversary, culminating in a screening of the best 16 films from the past two decades in the Tropfest All Star Competition. With judges Toni Collette (President of the Jury), [[Tobey Maguire]], [[Rebel Wilson]], [[James Woods]], [[Anthony LaPaglia]], Trevor Groth and Charles Randolph presiding over the competition, ''The Story of Bubble Boy'', directed by Sean Ascroft, ultimately took out the top prize.
A few weeks later, on 23 June 2012, Tropfest New York had its debut in [[Bryant Park]]. Hosted by Hugh Jackman and including musical performances by [[Alexi Murdoch]] and [[Milagres (band)|Milagres]], the festival attracted a crowd of approximately 10,000. Judges [[Rose Byrne]], [[Judah Friedlander]], [[Jennifer Westfeldt]], Scott Foundas and [[Ted Hope]] awarded the $20,000 first prize to director Josh Leake for his film ''Emptys''. Tropfest NY 2013 festival was held on 22 June in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, with a bridge as the signature item. In 2014 Tropfest postponed its New York event. The festival has said a 2015 event will be held, using a kiss as the signature item, which was originally announced for 2014.
Tropfest has one of the most successful channels on [[YouTube]], having attracted more than 31,000,000 video views for its films in a relatively short time period.{{clarify|date=January 2013}}
In February 2013 festival founder John Polson announced a change of date to 8 December and a change of venue from the Domain to [[Centennial Park, New South Wales|Centennial Park]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hardie|first1=Giles|title=It's time to leave home as Tropfest turns 21|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/its-time-to-leave-home-as-tropfest-turns-21-20130217-2el7m.html|accessdate=2 March 2015|publisher=Sydney Morning Herald|date=17 February 2013}}</ref> ''We feel like we are changing gears, we are growing every year and Centennial Park is in some ways the emotional heart of Sydney''
The winner of the December 2013 festival, ''Bamboozled'', was accused of [[homophobia]] and [[transphobia]].<ref name=news-bamboozled>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/movies/tropfest-winner-bamboozled-accused-of-transphobia/story-e6frfmvr-1226779160847|title=Tropfest winner Bamboozled accused of transphobia |date=9 December 2013|work=[[News Corp Australia]]|accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref> It is a comedy in which a man sleeps with a man he believes to be his [[transitioning (transgender)|transitioned]] ex-girlfriend.<ref name=news-bamboozled/>
==2015 cancellation== On 11 November Polson announced that the 2015 Sydney Tropfest had been cancelled. He said "... I have been made aware that the company contracted to raise the funding and administer the Tropfest event is unable to move forward for financial reasons.".<ref name=abc-2015-cancel>{{cite news |title=Tropfest short film festival cancelled over 'terrible mismanagement' of funds |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-11/tropfest-cancelled-over-terrible-mismanagement-of-funds/6933142 |accessdate=11 November 2015 |work=ABC News|agency=ABC |date=11 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=facebook-2015-cancel>{{cite web |title=2015 Tropfest Cancelled |url=https://www.facebook.com/tropfest/posts/973324956047111 |website=Facebook |publisher=Tropfest Pty Ltd |accessdate=11 November 2015 |date=11 November 2015}}</ref> CEO of Tropfest Festival Productions, Michael Laverty, has been unavailable for comment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/mlaverty18|title=Michael Laverty (@mlaverty18) - Twitter|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/tropfest-cancelled-after-huge-hole-in-funding-20151111-gkwoxv.html|title=Exclusive: Tropfest cancelled after 'huge hole' in funding|first=Garry|last=Maddox|date=11 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref>

Notes |- | Tropfest Australia || Centennial Parklands, [[Sydney]] || 6 December 2015 || Rescheduled for 14 February 2016<ref name=abc-tropfest-on /> |- | Tropfest South East Asia|| The Esplanade, [[Penang]] || 1 February 2015 || |- | Tropfest New Zealand || TSB Bowl of Brooklands, [[New Plymouth]] || 14 February 2015 || |- | Tropfest United States || Prospect Park, [[New York City]] || TBC || |- | [[Tropfest Arabia]] || TBC || TBC|| |- |}
===Financial difficulties=== Polsons said he had discovered to his “surprise” Tropfest was facing a financial crisis and could not proceed due to a lack of funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.9news.com.au/national/2015/11/12/05/20/tropfest-founder-launches-legal-action-as-festival-cancelled|title=Tropfest founder launches legal action as festival cancelled|publisher=}}</ref> It emerged the management company Polson had fallen out with over the alleged “mismanagement” of Tropfest funds was managed by Laverty, his long-time Tropfest partner and its managing director.
Over the following days it emerged suppliers and contracted partners of Tropfest have been experiencing payment delays for several months. As of 14 November Laverty was un-contactable for any comments.<ref name=d-tele-fallout/> Commercial entertainment services agency The Intersection, who was retained in 2014 by Tropfest issued a statement on Facebook stating its relationship with Tropfest ended in 2014 over a pay dispute.<ref name=d-tele-fallout>[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/tropfest-john-polson-and-michael-laverty-fall-out-over-funding-crisis/story-fni0cvc9-1227606938007 The Daily Telegraph]</ref>
An outpouring of support for Tropfest quickly appeared over social media, including Twitter and Facebook, with calls for generous benefactors, state or federal government support, or crowd-funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-12/tropfest-cancellation-public-reaction/6933336|title=Tropfest cancellation sparks outpouring of support|date=12 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref>
On 6 December Polson announced that the Sydney festival would be held in its intended venue, Centennial Park on Sunday, 14 February 2016. [[CGU Insurance]] is the source of the necessary extra funding.<ref name=abc-tropfest-on>{{cite news|title=Tropfest film festival set to return after securing financial lifeline, organisers say|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-12-06/tropfest-secures-financial-lifeline-organisers/7005144|accessdate=6 December 2015|work=ABC News|agency=ABC|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=6 December 2015}}</ref>
==Signature item== Each year, Tropfest requires that entries include a particular "signature item" or action to ensure that they are unique and are made specifically for the festival. No TSI was required for the 1993 festival. The following are TSIs by year:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tropfest.com/au/tsi/|title=TSI|publisher=Tropfest|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref> * 2019{{snd}}Candle * 2018{{snd}}Rose * 2017{{snd}}Pineapple * 2015{{snd}}Card * 2014{{snd}}Mirror * 2013, December{{snd}}Change * 2013, February{{snd}}Balloon * 2012{{snd}}Lightbulb * 2011{{snd}}Key * 2010{{snd}}Dice * 2009{{snd}}Spring * 2008{{snd}}The Number 8 * 2007{{snd}}Sneeze * 2006{{snd}}Bubble * 2005{{snd}}Umbrella * 2004{{snd}}Hook * 2003{{snd}}Rock * 2002{{snd}}Match * 2001{{snd}}Horn * 2000{{snd}}Bug * 1999{{snd}}Chopsticks * 1998{{snd}}Kiss * 1997{{snd}}Pickle * 1996{{snd}}Teaspoon * 1995{{snd}}Coffee Bean * 1994{{snd}}Muffin * 1993{{snd}}No TSI

{{hatnote|For the related lunar festivals celebrated on the same day, see [[Mid-Autumn Festival]] (across Chinese diaspora and Vietnam) and [[Chuseok]] (North and South Korea).}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Tsukimi |type = Asian |image = File:Tsukimi,moon-viewing-party,japan.JPG |imagesize = 200px |caption = Offerings for the September 13 Moon: Tsukimi dango (left), susuki grass (middle) and chestnuts (right) |official_name = Tsukimi (月見) |nickname = |observedby = Japanese |litcolor = |longtype = Cultural, religious ([[Buddhist]]) |significance = Celebrates the harvest |begins = 15th day of the 8th lunar month |ends=18th day of the 8th lunar month |date= September or October |date2018= 24-27 September |celebrations = |observances = Burn incense at temples and consume [[mochi]] |relatedto = [[Mid-Autumn Festival]] (in China and Vietnam)
[[Chuseok]] (in Korea)
[[Uposatha]] of [[Ashvini]]/[[Kṛttikā|Krittika]] (similar festivals that generally occur on the same day in Cambodia, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Laos, and Thailand ) |frequency = Annual }} {{Nihongo|'''Tsukimi'''|月見}} or {{Nihongo|'''Otsukimi'''|お月見}}, literally ''moon-viewing'', also known as {{Nihongo|'''Jugoya'''|十五夜}}, are Japanese festivals honoring the autumn moon, a variant of the [[Mid-Autumn Festival]]. The celebration of the [[full moon]] typically takes place on the 15th day of the eighth month of the traditional [[Japanese calendar]]; the [[Lunar phase|waxing moon]] is celebrated on the 13th day of the ninth month. These days normally fall in September and October of the modern [[solar calendar]]. The tradition dates to the [[Heian era]], and is now so popular in Japan that some people repeat the activities for several evenings following the appearance of the full moon during the eighth lunisolar month. Tsukimi traditions include displaying decorations made from [[Miscanthus sinensis|Japanese pampas grass]] (''susuki'') and eating rice dumplings called ''Tsukimi [[dango]]'' in order to celebrate the beauty of the moon.{{cite news|url=http://www.denverpost.com/2015/09/25/where-to-view-the-harvest-moon/|date=September 25, 2015|publisher=[[The Denver Post]]|author= Colleen Smith|title=Where to view the harvest moon?}} Seasonal produce are also displayed as offerings to the moon. [[Sweet potato]]es are offered to the full moon, while beans or chestnuts are offered to the waxing moon the following month. The alternate names of the celebrations, ''Imomeigetsu''　(literally "potato harvest moon") and ''Mamemeigetsu'' ("bean harvest moon") or ''Kurimeigetsu'' ("chestnut harvest moon") are derived from these offerings. ==History== Tsukimi refers to the Japanese tradition of holding parties to view the [[harvest moon]]. The custom is thought to have originated with Japanese aristocrats during the [[Heian period]],{{Citation needed|reason=reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=August 2011}} who would gather to recite [[poetry]] under the full moon of the eighth month of the [[solar calendar]], known as the "Mid-Autumn Moon." Since ancient times, Japanese people have described the eighth solar month (corresponding to September on the contemporary [[Gregorian calendar]]) as the best time for looking at the moon, since the relative positions of the earth, sun, and moon cause the moon to appear especially bright.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} On the evening of the full moon, it is traditional to gather in a place where the moon can be seen clearly, decorate the scene with Japanese pampas grass, and to serve white rice dumplings (known as ''Tsukimi dango''), [[taro]], [[edamame]], [[chestnut]]s and other seasonal foods, plus [[sake]] as offerings to the moon in order to pray for an abundant harvest. These dishes are known collectively as {{nihongo|Tsukimi dishes|月見料理|tsukimi ryōri}}. Due to the ubiquity of sweet potato or taro among these dishes, the tradition is known as {{nihongo|Imomeigetsu|芋名月}} or "Potato harvest moon" in some parts of Japan. From 862 until 1683, the Japanese calendar was arranged so that the full moon fell on the 13th day of each month. In 1684, however, the calendar was altered so that the [[new moon]] fell on the first day of each month, moving the full moon two weeks later, to the 15th day of the month. While some people in [[Edo]] (present-day [[Tokyo]]) shifted their Tsukimi activities to the 15th day of the month, others continued to observe the festival on the 13th day. Furthermore, there were various regional observances in some parts of Japan on the 17th day of the month, as well as Buddhist observances on the 23rd or the 26th day, all of which were used as pretexts for often late-night parties during the autumn throughout the [[Edo period]]. This custom was brought to a swift end during the [[Meiji period]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} Festivals dedicated to the moon have a long history in Japan. During the [[Heian period]] elements of the [[China|Chinese]] [[Mid-Autumn Festival]] were introduced to Japan. Members of the aristocratic class would hold moon-viewing events aboard boats in order to view the moon's reflection on the surface of the water. The writing of [[waka (poetry)|tanka]] poetry was also an element of such mid-autumn moon viewing festivities. There are specific terms in Japanese to refer to occasions when the moon is not visible on the traditional mid-autumn evening, including {{nihongo|Mugetsu|無月||"no-moon"}} and {{nihongo|Ugetsu|雨月||"rain-moon"}}. Even when the moon is not visible, however, Tsukimi parties are held. A Unicode [[emoji]] exists for Tsukimi, featuring pampas grass, dango and the moon{{cite news|last1=Connor|first1=Liz|title=This is what some of the weirdest emojis actually mean|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/world-emoji-day-this-is-what-some-of-the-weirdest-emojis-actually-mean-a3589416.html|accessdate=26 March 2018|work=Evening Standard}}. ==Related foods== It is traditional to serve Tsukimi [[dango]] and seasonal produce offerings during Tsukimi, as described above. In addition, there are several other dishes associated with Tsukimi. Boiled [[soba]] or [[udon]] noodles topped with [[nori]] and raw egg, then covered with broth are known as ''Tsukimi soba'' or ''Tsukimi udon''. In [[Kitakyushu]] an egg served atop [[yaki udon]] is known as ''Tenmado'', another name for Tsukimi in the local dialect. Similarly when a raw quail egg is used to top sushi, like battleship sushi [[gunkanzushi]] or a handroll [[temaki]] it is referred to as tsukimi style. Confectionary, such as [[Mooncake]]s, are also enjoyed. At some fast food restaurants in Japan a special Fall Menu is offered during September and October featuring [[fried egg]] sandwiches known as ''Tsukimi burgers''. ==See also== *[[List of harvest festivals]] *[[Chuseok]], the Korean autumn harvest festival held on the same day *[[Mid-Autumn Festival]], the Chinese moon-observance festival held on the same day *[[:ja:月見|月見]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Portal|Japan|Culture}} *{{Commonscat-inline|Mid-Autumn Festival}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-X371xoBUdA Moon Viewing Festival in Osaka] - [[Sumiyoshi taisha]] [[Category:Japanese culture]] [[Category:Harvest festivals]] [[Category:Lunar observation]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian September observances]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian October observances]]
